In instances of a population being dumped onto a distributed 
processing en=
viroment for fitness evaluation, and a random input is 
required as part of=
 the fitness evaluation, the cited issues come 
into play above and beyond =
the NEAT internal random number usage.


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Coli=
n Green" <locster01@...> wrote:
>
> Thanks for this. It's interesting to th=
at George Marsaglia's KISS 
RNG
> is given the thumbs up, I used his XOR sh=
ift algorithm as the basis
> for my FastRandom class in SharpNeat. I may we=
ll switch over to 
using
> the KISS algorithm though based on the discussio=
n in this article. 
Oh
> and also someone made a comment on the codeproject=
 page where
> FastRandom lives - "Worst ever random generator!...Passes FIP=
S 140-1
> with approximately 0.7 %. "
> 
> Not sure why this guy was so pas=
sionate about RNG's but I do intend 
to
> check out this FIPS test one day.=

> 
> Overall though I don't think NEAT is going to be particularly harmed
=
> by the kind of flaws inherent in some of these RNGs. For most of 
what
> =
we do we just want uniformly distributed numbers to mix things up a
> bit. =
Any patterns in the generated sequence probably aren't
> particularly detri=
mental IMHO. Interested to know if others agree or
> not.
> 
> Colin
>
